duties:
These senior TA positions focus on supporting the complex collaboration and systems prototyping aspects of ESC204. The course is a 2nd year engineering design course that helps students build skills around effective teamwork, project management, understanding unfamiliar design contexts and stakeholders, technical design and prototyping, and communication. The complex collaboration parts comprise effective teamwork, project management, understanding unfamiliar design contexts and stakeholders, and aspects of working together on prototypes. One senior TAs will serve as a lead in this area. The other will serve as lead in the area of systems prototyping as well as help manage the course website and platforms. Both senior TAs will collaborate with the faculty co-leads and Communication CI (hired separately through ECP) to ensure that content and content delivery aligns across all areas of the course. You will support the faculty course instructors to develop and deliver the content for the course. In addition, you will support studio TAs to facilitate studios related to your areas. The systems prototyping lead will also support studio TAs to facilitate interactions between students and course partners such as the Myhal Fabrication Facility: https://www.engineering.utoronto.ca/myhal-centre-for-engineering-innovation-entrepreneurship/ 

Senior TAs also provide informal feedback and support to students during studio times, and help with formal assessment of student work. Senior TAs are encourages to attend at least one lecture each week, and must attend weekly core team meetings (with the course co-instructors, Communication CI, and senior TAs) and weekly course meetings (that includes the Studio TAs). You will also attend benchmarking meetings with Assessment TAs for assignments that relate to complex collaboration. Core team meetings are to discuss how the previous week went, what is planned for the following week, what is being covered in lectures and studios, and discuss any problems that may have arisen. Weekly course team meetings will include a debrief of the previous week’s studio activities, plans for the following week’s studio activities, lecture content overviews, and discussion of any problems that may have arisen. Meetings will be held in hybrid format with in-person attendance encouraged. 

Studio sessions are planned to be held in-person, unless there are changes to health policies that prevent in-person course delivery. Lectures will be delivered in hybrid format for accommodation reasons. Any changes to the course delivery (in-person, online, or a hybrid of both), will be communicated by the University at a later date.  

All course instructional staff are required to go through Myhal Fabrication Facility Safety Training. In addition, Myhal Fabrication Facility will provide training on basic digital prototyping and fabrication to all course instructional staff. Senior TAs will support the instructors in facilitating trainings of Studio and Assessment and Feedback TAs prior to the start of the course. All trainings are paid time.

appointment_size: Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled, therefore minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed
application_procedure:
•  Complete application form before closing date (June 13th at 11:59 PM). Applicants must be signed in to their UofT webmail account to access the form. 
• Application form link: https://forms.office.com/r/7PvkvSzKTT. If you are experiencing technical difficulties with the form, email accessexams.utsc@utoronto.ca to report the issues you are having
Applicants submit:
•  Resume and cover letter. Address application to Jenny Hon, Test & Exam Coordinator
•  University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN
•  Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above
•  NOTE: Incomplete applications will not be considered
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations written by students with documented disabilities who are registered with AccessAbility Services at the University of Toronto, Scarborough (UTSC). 
Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
• Supervision of in-person tests and examinations written by persons who write with disability-related accommodations. Some remote shifts may be required
• Through active invigilation, maintain the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
• Maintaining confidentiality and security of student and test/exam information
• Ensuring the provision of disability-related accommodations to students as authorized by AccessAbility Services
• Monitoring test/exam time allotments
• Handling student concerns/problems and referring to Test and Exam Coordinator where appropriate
• Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
• Preparing completed in-person tests/exams for return delivery 
• Verifying student identification
• Maintaining required administrative records
• Ensuring the physical exam space, including supply cabinet, Invigilator work station, and students' writing areas, are kept clean and organized
qualifications:
• Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto  
• Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion 
• Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts
• Preference will be given to candidates who have experience working with persons with disabilities
• Experience invigilating tests/exams is an asset
• First Aid and CPR certification is an asset
• Experience with Zoom is an asset
• Applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:30 AM - 10:30 PM, Monday through Saturday
• A minimum of 10 hours of availability must be provided each week between Mondays - Fridays from 7:30 AM to 6 PM AND
• A minimum of 45 hours of availability must be provided during all final exam periods. N.B. Occasional Sunday shifts may also be required
Successful candidates must participate in mandatory training, which will consist of:
• January Orientation sessions: more details to follow
• New Invigilators are required to participate in a minimum of 3 in-person shadow shifts prior to the examination period
• New Invigilators are required to participate in preliminary in-person independent shifts after completion of their shadow shifts
Please note that all aspects of training will be scheduled between 7:30 AM - 5:00 PM Monday through Saturday.
Successful candidates must attend three final exam meetings to be held the week before deferred and final exam period begins. The meetings will be scheduled between 8:30 AM – 5:00 PM, Mondays to Fridays.
• Ability to respond effectively to emergency, difficult or sensitive situations while maintaining appropriate boundaries
• Problem solving and resourcefulness
• Ability to remain calm under pressure  
• Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities
• Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation 
• Initiative
• Interpersonal
• Organizational
• Communication (both oral and written)
• Strong computer skills, including MS Office; Experience with assistive technology and Zoom an asset
